description: From Middle English pinte, from Old French pinte, assumed from Vulgar Latin *pincta (“a mark used to indicate a level of quantity against a larger measure”), from Latin picta (“painted”), from Latin pingō (“paint”, verb). Doublet of pinto and Pinto.

definitionGroups.group: A unit of volume, equivalent to:

entries.meaning: one eighth of a gallon, specifically:
(UK, Commonwealth) 20 fluid ounces, approximately 568 millilitres (an imperial pint)
16 US fluid ounces [473 millilitres] for liquids (a US liquid pint) or
approximately 18.62 fluid ounces [551 millilitres] for dry goods (a US dry pint).

examples: Please leave three pints tomorrow, milkman.

entries.meaning: (UK, metonymically) A glass of beer or cider, served by the pint.
examples: A couple of pints please, barman.
